attributes.title: COVID-19 Interpersonal Coping Study
attributes.description: A daily diary study focusing on interpersonal coping, isolation, and well-being during the COVID-19 pandemic of 2020. We are pre-registering our methods and measures, but our specific analyses will largely be exploratory based on a set of guiding research questions.

summary.value: We have included a pre-registration document summarizing methods and research questions, as well as an appendix that includes our measures.

registration_responses.summary: We have included a pre-registration document summarizing methods and research questions, as well as an appendix that includes our measures.

attributes.title: An empirical investigation of autistic-like traits and body satisfaction on attentional bias in a non-clinical sample.
attributes.description: This is my thesis project pre-registration.

data.value: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

name.value:
An empirical investigation of autistic-like traits and body dissatisfaction on attentional bias in a non-clinical sample.

Study investigating the role of attentional bias in sub-clinical profiles of both autism and eating disorders. Pattern recognition is evident in both populations however this superiority has not yet been investigated together.

sample.value: A proposed total of 30 female adults (18+ years of age) will be recruited for this study. The sample size is justified through previous literature around eye-tracking studies. The participants will be recruited through opportunity sampling through different sampling strategies which include poster advertisement around Northumbria University as well as advertisement on personal social media platforms. The study will additionally be promoted on SONA System, where participants will receive 4 points for participation in this study. Exclusion criteria includes any previous diagnosis of visual impairment that cannot be corrected by glasses

analyses.value: The study will utilize a spatial analysis for initial assessment of the data. This entails the recording of eye-movements of each CGI stimulus allowing for simple fixation count per cell. The independent groups design will enable the comparison of the fixation density in all three groups (Low ALT’s/High BS, High ALT’s/High BS and Low ALT’s/Low BS). With each participant contributing several fixations to the sampling grid to the range of images. The production of an average body size with the fixation density is then calculated from body image CGI stimuli for each participant. Subsequently, a script is produced which measures the locations of significant differences between the three participant groups. Once the final three images are constructed, heat maps are used to explore the differences of gaze patterns between the three groups. Once the differences between the three groups are identified, a t-test approach will be employed, allowing for statistical significance for each cell accepting the spatial conversion

outliers.value: The study is yet to receive ethical approval from Northumbria Ethics Committee. This pre-registration document has been submitted to meet the demands of MRes Psychology course for one of the modules. The study is still subject to change following ethical approval, where the application will be re-submitted with any new corrections. Therefore outliers have not yet been discussed.

dependent.value: The key dependent variable measure is the gaze patterns in the form of fixation density. This will be retrieved from the Eyelink 1000.

conditions.value:
The study will consist of three independent groups with two levels:

Condition 1: High autistic traits/High body dissatisfaction 

Condition 2: High autistic-like traits/Low body dissatisfaction 

Condition 3: Low autistic-like traits/Low body dissatisfaction

hypothesis.value:
This study aims to explore the casual relationship between the presence of high autistic like traits and body satisfaction on attentional bias towards the female body. More specifically, if the presence of ALT’s influences processing of own BMI estimation when the individual presents either high or low body satisfaction profile. Moreover, the study aims to explore whether present such profile will be an advantage in terms of pattern recognition when estimating own BMI as well as the pattern recognition when making judgements around others in terms of judgement of estimation of others body size. Therefore, the present study hypothesizes:

H1: There will be a significant difference of pattern recognition in terms of fixation density between individuals with high and low BD, with high BD females presenting clear attentional bias towards the mid body (waist, hips, arms, legs). 

H2: There will be a difference between pattern recognition between participants with high autistic-like traits and low autistic like traits, specifically females who have high ALT’s will present a strong attentional bias towards the mid-body. 

H3: There will be a difference between fixation density between the self-related pattern recognition (BMI estimation) compared to other related pattern recognition (Fat/thin estimation), the attentional bias will be highlighted in body estimation task with females directing their gaze to most informative mid-body areas whereas fat/thin estimation will be driven by attentional bias towards the body as a whole. 

The current research question for this proposed study is” Do autistic-like traits and body satisfaction have an impact on attentional bias in a non-clinical sample?”.

registration_responses.data: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

attributes.title: AnalysAttributions About and Responses to Imagined Future Romantic Partners’ Behaviors: Links to Adolescent Attachment to Parents
attributes.description: Changes to the analysis plan for the project.

summary.value:
We are writing this second pre-registration to amend some aspects of the pre-registered analysis plan.  The overarching motivation of these changes stems from the first author’s continued learning of best practices in statistics from her graduate coursework. 

Change #1: Primary Analyses
We previously planned to run ten different models for our primary analyses.  We have simplified this and will now be combining these models into one measured variable path analysis. We believe this will allow for a more accurate depiction of the relations among variables in the system.  All predictors, covariates, and interaction terms will be set to covary. We will also allow the errors to covary for our two outcome measures of responses to conflict (explicit responses and implicit responses).

Change #2: Covariates
We previously planned to include only empirically derived covariates in our primary analyses (just including variables that are significantly correlated with our outcome variables as covariates).  We have since decided to include the following a priori covariates: age, race (minority vs non-minority), preferred partner gender, romantic relationship experience (some or none), and school. In addition, we will test the correlations between the remaining demographic variables (e.g., maternal education level) and our outcome variables, and include variables with significant correlations as covariates. We are making this change to avoid omitting a covariate with a low bivariate correlation with an outcome variable, despite having a significant direct effect on that outcome variable. 

We will not include participant gender as a covariate in the primary analyses due to possible multicollinearity issues with preferred partner gender. We may include participant gender in exploratory analyses.

Change #3: Missing Data
We had previously planned to use multiple imputation for missing data. We did not specify item level or scale level.  We now plan on using Full Information Maximum Likelihood (FIML) for scale level missingness. This is because FIML is well integrated with path analysis statistical packages and yields similar estimates to multiple imputation (Graham et al., 2007). For item level missingness, we will use participant mean imputation (Parent, 2013) as it yields similar estimates to multiple imputation, while allowing us to use more of our available data. 

Change #4: Statistical Software
We previously planned on conducting all analyses in R.  We now may also conduct some analyses in Mplus, as Mplus can be very useful for path analyses.

Change #5: Psychometric Analysis
In my pilot analyses, we explored the psychometric properties of the data with Cronbach’s alpha.  Moving forward, we will use McDonald’s omega instead. This is because McDonald’s omega is less biased than Cronbach’s alpha when the assumption of tau equivalence is not met. 

Current project status: We have completed data collection and data cleaning. We have not conducted any hypothesis testing.  

References:

Graham, J. W., Olchowski, A. E., & Gilreath, T. D. (2007). How many imputations are really needed? Some practical clarifications of multiple imputation theory. Prevention Science, 8(3), 206–213. 

Parent, M. C. (2013). Handling item-level missing data: Simpler is just as good. The Counseling Psychologist, 41(4), 568–600.

Parent, M. C. (2013). Handling item-level missing data: Simpler is just as good. The Counseling Psychologist, 41(4), 568–600.

attributes.title: Honor and Moral Foundations
attributes.description: This is a correlational study examining how the cultural variable of honor ideology relates to the five moral foundations. To our knowledge, no study has yet examined the relationship between these variables.

q2.value:
We hypothesize that honor ideology will be positively related to the binding moral foundations of loyalty, authority, and purity, given the theoretical conceptualizations of honor's values and beliefs, as well as observed phenomena within the honor literature. 

We hypothesize that associations between honor ideology and the individualizing foundations of care and fairness will be modest, if they exist at all.

q3.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: This study is a within-subjects correlational design. All participants complete all measures. The measures of honor ideology, as well as all relevant covariates, were completed as a part of departmental mass-testing. The outcome variables, the moral foundations measures, were completed at a separate time.

q8.value: Registration prior to analysis of the data

q9.value: Neither of the researchers involved in this study have conducted analysis on these specific variables for this project (although the measures from mass-testing have been matched to other datasets as a part of unrelated projects). We have intentionally refrained from conducting any analysis of this data related to this project before pre-registration.

question.value: Participants access the survey from SONA and complete the survey in exchange for course credit. The survey is administered in an online format via a link to Qualtrics. Participants must be 18 years old.

q11.value: 176 participants have been matched back to prescreening.

q12.value: A priori power analysis revealed this number to be suitable for achieving adequate power.

q13.value: Data were collected up to the end of the window for participation on SONA prior to the mid-semester break.

question.value: The Honor Ideology for Manhood (HIM), Honor Ideology for Womanhood (HIW), and Honor Concerns Scale (HC) were administered as part of departmental mass-testing, as were simple demographic items; political identification, gender, age, socio-economic status, and education level. The Moral Foundations measure (the subscales of which are our outcome variables) was administered at a separate occasion, and was matched back to the mass-testing data.

The Moral Foundations measure will be combined into each of the contained subscales by averaging the scores on each subscale's items. The HIM, HIW, and HC will be averaged into each scale total, and this will be subjected to an exploratory factor analysis using principle axis factoring to produce a latent variable measuring honor ideology, as has been done previously in the honor literature.

Simple bivariate correlations will be done between all variables of interest to identify basic relationships between these variables. 

Multiple regression models will then be conducted regressing each of the moral foundations onto the latent honor factor, as well as the control variables of political ideology, gender, age, SES, and education level. These models will be sequential, meaning the first model will consist of only the control variables, and the second model will include honor alongside these variables, to assess if it significantly changes the model's explanatory power.

q18.value: Categorical variables (such as Gender) will be effect coded. All other predictors will be mean-centered.

q19.value: We will use the standard criterion for significance of p < .05.

q20.value: Participants will be excluded if they do not answer a majority (75% or more) of questions for any measure, or if they indicated that they did not consent to their data being included in analyses.

q21.value: If the majority of a measure has not been completed, their data will be excluded.

We hypothesize that honor ideology will be positively related to the binding moral foundations of loyalty, authority, and purity, given the theoretical conceptualizations of honor's values and beliefs, as well as observed phenomena within the honor literature. 

We hypothesize that associations between honor ideology and the individualizing foundations of care and fairness will be modest, if they exist at all.

attributes.title: Identification of individuals at Risk for severe COVID-19 after SARS-CoV-2 Infection based on clinical, laboratory variables and image features: a systematic review and meta-analysis. Short title: Characteristics for patients with severe COVID-19
attributes.description: The pooled overall, demographic and geographic characteristics of clinical symptoms, laboratory variables and image features for patients at different stages of COVID-19 are rare. The present systematic review and meta-analysis aimed to identify factors or biomarkers for the development of severe COVID-19 that could be useful in clinical practice.

summary.value: COVID-19 has an outbreak globally, as a direct cause of epidemic, morbidity and mortality. Demographic and geographic characteristics of clinical symptoms, laboratory test and image features at different stages of COVID-19 patients are important for early detection. However, no studies have systematically examined the characteristics of clinical, laboratory, and imaging variables in detecting severe Novel Coronavirus (COVID-19).

registration_responses.summary: COVID-19 has an outbreak globally, as a direct cause of epidemic, morbidity and mortality. Demographic and geographic characteristics of clinical symptoms, laboratory test and image features at different stages of COVID-19 patients are important for early detection. However, no studies have systematically examined the characteristics of clinical, laboratory, and imaging variables in detecting severe Novel Coronavirus (COVID-19).

attributes.title: Personality and responses to the coronavirus pandemic
attributes.description: Adaptive and Dark Personality in the Covid-19 Pandemic: Predicting Health-behavior Endorsement and the Appeal of Public-health Messages

summary.value:
General Background
The literature on general personality and physical health has focused primarily on broad health outcomes and, to an extent, on specific health behaviors. Responses to a pandemic, particularly with regard to hygiene and social distancing, have not been examined. The literature on psychopathy and the dark triad has linked these characteristics to risk-taking and, in few studies, to physical health outcomes, and there is an increasing interested in psychopathy, the dark triad, and everyday behavior. These traits have not yet been linked to hygiene and social distancing in a pandemic. Finally, personality has been linked to responses to political and commercial messaging, but not to public health messaging. The emergent coronavirus pandemic presents an opportunity to test hypotheses in this area at a time when most people in the U.S. are at least somewhat informed about the pandemic and are still adapting to new demands for social distancing, increased hygiene, and public-health messages.

The study being registered will link general personality (the Big Five), the triarchic psychopathy model, and the dark triad to self-reported current and intended hygiene and social distancing, to self-reported endorsement of intent to harm others by spreading the infection, and to the personal appeal of public-health messaging about how to protect oneself and others from the virus. Specific predictions are listed following the method description.

Method Basics
Research participants will be up to 500 Mechanical Turk Workers, to be compensated $1.5 for a 15-min. survey. The survey will consist of ad hoc questionnaires about hygiene, social distancing, social and self-protective behaviors, intent to harm others, the mini-IPIP scales (Donnellan et al., 2006), Abbreviated Psychopathy Measure (Semel, 2018), Short Dark Triad (Jones & Paulhus, 2014), and brief scales to measure the persuasiveness, likelihood to take seriously, and likelihood to impact behavior of each of five public-health messages. The messages have been written ad hoc and based to theory to use language that would especially appeal to or be ego-syntonic with narcissistic/Machiavellian, conscientious/overcontrolled, agreeable/compassionate, avoidant/contamination-averse, and extraverted/sociable personalities. Composite scores will be created from the personality questionnaires according to their conventional scoring guidelines. Composite scores will be created for the health-related questionnaires to create the following variables: Current social distancing; current hygiene; intent to socially distance; intent for hygiene; willigness to harm others; message appeal (separately for each of the five messages). The correlational analyses linking personality variables to the health-related composites will control for age, sex, and the extent to which participants report having chronic health conditions that may make them especially susceptible to coronavirus (on a scale from 0-2).  

Power and Data Cleaning
Partial correlations will be considered significant at p <= .01 (one-tailed). This corresponds to .85 power at alpha = .01 (one-tailed) for an r = .16 with N = 430. We will attempt to obtain valid data from up to 500 participants, based on budget limitations. Realistically, we expect that approximately 60 out of 500 participants will provide data with questionable validity. This will be determined through the use of validity and consistency check, and survey-completion times. We will plot the survey-completion times and look for an inversion point that distinguishes extremely fast completion times from more realistic completion times. We anticipate excluding the participants with the 25 lowest completion times, but we must inspect the actual completion-time data before committing to this decision. We will examine responses to three pairs of inconsistency check questions, to three validity questions (e.g., I am answering these questions truthfully), and to three questions expected to produce nearly constant responses. We will examine the distribution of these inconsistency/validity data and exclude extremely inconsistent/invalid responses. We anticipate excluding participants (probably around 50-60) who fail 2-3 of the inconsistency check and 2-3 of the validity checks, but we must inspect the actual inconsistency/validity data before committing to this decision. We do not anticipate engaging in other data cleaning or in the identification or selection of outliers.

Specific Predictions
Self-reported inclination to engage in social distancing will correlate with:
- Conscientiousness, Agreeableness, Neuroticism, Boldness (negatively), Disinhibition (negatively), and Psychopathy (negatively)
Self-reported inclination to engage in hygiene will correlate with:
- Conscientiousness, Agreeableness, Disinhibition (negatively), Meanness (negatively)
Self-reported actual engagement in social distancing will correlate with:
- Conscientiousness, Agreeableness, Extraversion (negatively), Neuroticism, Boldness (negatively), Disinhibition (negatively)
Self-reported actual engagement in hygiene practice will correlate with:
- Conscientiousness, Agreeableness, Narcissism (because of a desirability bias) and Boldness (for the same reason)
Self-reported willingness to deliberately infect others will correlate with:
- Meanness, Disinhibition, Machiavellianism, Psychopathy
Finally, appeal of the five public-health messages will correlate differentially with the traits:
The narcissistic/Machiavellian message: Narcissism, Meanness, Machiavellianism, Psychopathy;
The conscientious/overcontrolled message: Conscientiousness and Disinhibition (negative);
The agreeable/compassionate message: Conscientiousness, Agreeableness, Narcissism (negative), Machiavellianism (negative), Psychopathy (negative), and Meanness (negative);
The avoidant/fearful message: Neuroticism and Boldness (negative)
The extraverted message: Extraversion, Boldness, and Openness.

How does this summary differ from prior registrations?
There are no prior registrations of similar projects. This is a unique project that takes advantage of the emergent coronavirus pandemic. The IRB proposal was submitted on March 19, 2020, and data collection is expected to take place before the end of March, 2020 (pending IRB and budget approval).

General Background
The literature on general personality and physical health has focused primarily on broad health outcomes and, to an extent, on specific health behaviors. The literature on psychopathy and the dark triad has linked these characteristics to risk-taking and, in few studies, to physical health outcomes, and there is an increasing interested in psychopathy, the dark triad, and everyday behavior. The messages have been written ad hoc and based to theory to use language that would especially appeal to or be ego-syntonic with narcissistic/Machiavellian, conscientious/overcontrolled, agreeable/compassionate, avoidant/contamination-averse, and extraverted/sociable personalities. Composite scores will be created from the personality questionnaires according to their conventional scoring guidelines. Power and Data Cleaning
Partial correlations will be considered significant at p <= .01 (one-tailed). This corresponds to .85 power at alpha = .01 (one-tailed) for an r = .16 with N = 430. We will attempt to obtain valid data from up to 500 participants, based on budget limitations. This will be determined through the use of validity and consistency check, and survey-completion times. We anticipate excluding participants (probably around 50-60) who fail 2-3 of the inconsistency check and 2-3 of the validity checks, but we must inspect the actual inconsistency/validity data before committing to this decision. We do not anticipate engaging in other data cleaning or in the identification or selection of outliers.

Specific Predictions
Self-reported inclination to engage in social distancing will correlate with:
- Conscientiousness, Agreeableness, Neuroticism, Boldness (negatively), Disinhibition (negatively), and Psychopathy (negatively)
Self-reported inclination to engage in hygiene will correlate with:
- Conscientiousness, Agreeableness, Disinhibition (negatively), Meanness (negatively)
Self-reported actual engagement in social distancing will correlate with:
- Conscientiousness, Agreeableness, Extraversion (negatively), Neuroticism, Boldness (negatively), Disinhibition (negatively)
Self-reported actual engagement in hygiene practice will correlate with:
- Conscientiousness, Agreeableness, Narcissism (because of a desirability bias) and Boldness (for the same reason)
Self-reported willingness to deliberately infect others will correlate with:
- Meanness, Disinhibition, Machiavellianism, Psychopathy
Finally, appeal of the five public-health messages will correlate differentially with the traits:
The narcissistic/Machiavellian message: Narcissism, Meanness, Machiavellianism, Psychopathy;
The conscientious/overcontrolled message: Conscientiousness and Disinhibition (negative);
The agreeable/compassionate message: Conscientiousness, Agreeableness, Narcissism (negative), Machiavellianism (negative), Psychopathy (negative), and Meanness (negative);
The avoidant/fearful message: Neuroticism and Boldness (negative)
The extraverted message: Extraversion, Boldness, and Openness.

How does this summary differ from prior registrations?
There are no prior registrations of similar projects. This is a unique project that takes advantage of the emergent coronavirus pandemic. The IRB proposal was submitted on March 19, 2020, and data collection is expected to take place before the end of March, 2020 (pending IRB and budget approval).

attributes.title: Dietary Patterns and Bayesian Choice
attributes.description: Some limited research has indicated cognitive benefits to some dietary patterns (e.g., the Mediterranean diet may improve cognitive outcomes in certain populations).  We attempt to further this line of research by examine samples of individuals who self-report specific dietary patterns.  Out cognitive measure will be more targeted than previously examined, as participants will be administered an incentivized Bayesian Choice task with the online survey delivery method we will use.

q3.value: Some limited research has indicated cognitive benefits to some dietary patterns (e.g., the Mediterranean diet may improve cognitive outcomes in certain populations).  We attempt to further this line of research by examine samples of individuals who self-report specific dietary patterns.  Out cognitive measure will be more targeted than previously examined, as participants will be administered an incentivized Bayesian Choice task with the online survey delivery method we will use.

q4.value:
Hypothesis 1:  We hypothesize those who indicate adherence to a Mediterranean, Vegetarian, or no-sugar diet will make probability assessments (i.e., Bayesian probability estimates) that are significantly more accurate than those indicating they do not follow any dietary pattern.  We hypothesize that the greatest effect of dietary pattern on Bayesian accuracy will be among those following a Mediterranean dietary pattern.  

Hypothesis 2:  Improvements in Bayesian accuracy by those following the Mediterranean, sugar-free, or vegetarian dietary patterns will be primarily observed in more difficult Bayesian choice environments (e.g., such as those where the two sources of information regarding the likely state of the world in the decision task point to opposite states).

Hypothesis 3.  More Bayesian accurate decisions will be associated with longer task response times.  This will be most apparent in the more difficult Bayesian choice trials.

Hypothesis 4:  Those following a Mediterranean, sugar-free, or vegetarian dietary pattern will show more Bayesian decision tendencies (e.g., weighting both sources of information in making choice), with the greatest Bayesian tendencies being for those following a Mediterranean diet.

q5.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: Samples of individual who self-report different dietary patterns will be obtained from the Prolific survey platform and all administered a common survey that includes a Bayesian choice task.  The task is repeated measures as it administers a 20-trial Bayesian task to each participant.  Equal sample size of n=100 will be obtained from each of 4 sample groups.

q9.value: The Bayes task contains 20 trials of decision making.  The task will present the trials in randomized order to all participants (all subjects see the same full set of 20 trials).

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
Using the Prolific survey software database, we will administer 4 studies, each one to a specific sample using the filters available in Prolific (our survey will include a double check on the filters, as some participants may list as vegetarian in the Prolific database at the time of completing their profile, but may have since changed to another dietary pattern).
Each study will filter for participants who are between 18 and 45 years of age, and the separate samples will filter for those who self-report adherence to the following dietary patterns: Mediterranean, no-sugar, Vegetarian, No dietary pattern.
We will administer a pilot study of n=10 participants to check for survey issues and payment level (subjects are paid a flat fee that must adhere to Prolific fair-pay standards, and the survey will additionally incentivize the Bayes task).  The pilot data will not be analyzed as part of the main study data analysis.
The main study will administer the survey to n=100 participants for each of the 4 desired dietary pattern samples.  The duration of the data gathering should last no more than 2 days from initiation of the main study.

q13.value:
See above.....n=100 participants per sample will be analyzed.  We anticipate recruitment of up to 110 for each sample to account for possible unusable data (e.g., failure of poison pill question in survey).
The total sample size will be n=400 (or slightly above) participants.

q14.value: Sample size was chosen based on a balance of statistical power and budget.  N=100 per dietary choice group gives us sufficient power=.80 to identify medium-small sized (f-squared=.08) main effects within each subsample (e.g, gender effect, effect of Hard versus Easy Bayesian trials).  This is based on an ex ante power analysis for a single regression coefficient within a multiples linear regression with alpha=.05 in G*Power version 3.1.9.2.  We also calculate medium power (f-squared=.20) to identify an interaction effect within the subsample if having at least n=40 per factor used for a moderating variable.  If pooling data from all groups, we expect greater statistical power to identify the main effect impact of one dietary choice group over another.  Additionally, individual trial level analysis (as opposed to generating a singular composite "accuracy" score per participant will deliver additional statistical power in our design

q15.value: Data collection will stop upon reaching the specified sample of 100-110 participants per dietary pattern group.

question.value: Indicator variables will identify each specific dietary group when pooling our subsamples.  Within the set of Bayesian stimuli (20 trials), the "base rate" and "new evidence" values are manipulated and presented in randomized order to each participant.  This is done such that there is a mix of relatively easier trials (where the Bayesian odds in favor of the more likely state is more extreme) versus hard trials.

We will measure:
--age
--gender
--strength of adherence to reported dietary pattern
--whether dietary pattern is medically necessary or voluntary
--whether any dietary supplement are taken (and what they are)
--comprehension test (i.e., poison pill question) mid-survey.
--For Bayesian task we will measure Response Time (RT) of choice for each stimulus and we will also measure the assessed probability of whether the trial was in one state (i.e., "LEFT box selected") or the other state (i.e., "RIGHT box selected") for that trial.
--In addition to use of individual trial decision outcomes (i.e., probability assessments) on a given participant, we will also score an alternative "rough-accuracy" measure equal to 1 if the participant is at least correct in identifying the statistically more likely scenario (given the information).  For example, if the Bayesian odds that the LEFT Box was selected in a trial is 93% likely but two different participants assess the odds at 61% and 79%, then the second participant is more accurate, but both would be given Rough-Accuracy=1 for that trial given they both indicated that the LEFT box was more likely than the RIGHT box.  This "rough accuracy" measure can be used for comparative analysis with existing studies in the literature, which used a similar task but simply asked participants to indicate which Box they felt had been selected in a particular trial.
--A simple measure of cognitive style will be measured via a 6-item Cognitive Reflection Task (CRT).  RT will also be assessed on the CRT task.

We will combine the accuracy measure of each trial to indicate how overall accurate the participant was over the full set of trials, and over the subset of Easier versus Harder trials.

The CRT will also combine total number of correct response across the set of 6 question to create the overall CRT score.  One might also combine response in to the total number incorrect response that seemed intuitively correct (but were wrong).

In general, we plan on unconditional analysis using nonparametric tests (e.g., Mann Whitney), which can be conducted on individual specific measures such as overall accuracy or RTs (pooled across all trials for a given individual), and these can be separated by Hard versus Easy trials.
More comprehensively, conditional individual level analysis will examine predictors of Bayesian accuracy, decision process, and response times, with clustering of errors at the individual level to account for the panel nature of the data.  We plan to include controls for CRT score, gender, strength of adherence to one's dietary pattern, supplement use,  and voluntary versus medically required dietary pattern.  
The main effect of dietary pattern on Bayesian accuracy, decision weights, or RTs will be the primary independent variable of interest.  We plan to examine interaction effects of dietary pattern with the difficulty of the Bayesian task.  Determinants of one's assessment of a more versus less likely Box will examine the main impact of new evidence versus prior odds in making one's "rough accuracy" assessment as well as one's point assessment estimate.

q21.value: For all hypotheses where we have indicated a directional prediction, one-tailed tests will be used.  Exploratory analysis of no-sugar versus Vegetarian dietary impacts is an example of where we will use a 2-tailed test, given we have no ex ante hypothesis as to which dietary pattern may be of more importance in Bayesian choice.

q22.value: Pilot data (n=10) will be excluded from main study analysis.  Additionally, analysis will be conducted both with and without participants who failed the poison pill question.

q24.value:
An exploratory analysis will involve evaluating the relative effects of the sugar-free versus vegetarian dietary patterns on choice.  These represent two dietary patterns that may contribute to some of the cognitive benefits of the Mediterranean diet (which is higher in vegetables on lower in added sugars than a typical "no dietary pattern" individual).

Previous studies have conducted analysis on each individual subject to generate a measure of the relative importance of existing versus new information in one's decision process.  Our study may have relatively low statistical power to do this (n=20 observations per subject for such an exercise), but we may conduct exploratory analysis estimating decision model at the individual participant level to measure relative decision making importance of base rates versus new evidence across dietary groups.

Other exploratory analysis will examine potential interaction effects with CRT, gender, or medically/voluntary dietary pattern.

We attempt to further this line of research by examine samples of individuals who self-report specific dietary patterns.  Out cognitive measure will be more targeted than previously examined, as participants will be administered an incentivized Bayesian Choice task with the online survey delivery method we will use.

Hypothesis 3.  More Bayesian accurate decisions will be associated with longer task response times.  This will be most apparent in the more difficult Bayesian choice trials.

Hypothesis 4:  Those following a Mediterranean, sugar-free, or vegetarian dietary pattern will show more Bayesian decision tendencies (e.g., weighting both sources of information in making choice), with the greatest Bayesian tendencies being for those following a Mediterranean diet.
